div.p: ANTONIO: Setting goals and planning for rewards in our future is a great way to motivate ourselves in making low-risk choices.
ANTONIO: But aside from the obvious appeal of being able to do something or to purchase something we've wanted, what are some things that make low-risk choices so important?
ALAN: Making change can be difficult, and sometimes all the work we need to do to maintain it seems hard, or boring.
ALAN: Fortunately, the human brain is wired to respond to rewards, and we can use that by planning ways to reward ourselves for sticking to our new choices.
ALAN: Rewarding ourselves isn't just a motivational gimmick... it has an important biological benefit.
ALAN: When we reward ourselves with positive things, such as volunteering, or buying something we've saved for, our brains respond the same way as they do when making high-risk choices.
ALAN: So, if we reward ourselves for making low-risk choices, the impact on the brain is similar to the good feeling we get from making high risk choices.
